What will be the output of the following C code?


int main() {
    int arr[] = {10, 20, 30, 40, 50};
    int *p = arr;
    printf("%d\n", *(p + 3));
    return 0;
}

What does the following code snippet do?


struct Student {
    char name[50];
    int age;
};
int main() {
    struct Student s1 = {"Alice", 20};
    struct Student s2 = s1;
    printf("%s, %d", s2.name, s2.age);
    return 0;
}

options.a: Copies the contents of s1 to s2
options.b: Swaps the values of s1 and s2

questions.question:
What will be the output of the following C code?


#define MULTIPLY(a, b) a * b
int main() {
    printf("%d\n", MULTIPLY(2 + 3, 3 + 4));
    return 0;
}

What is the output of the following code snippet?


int main() {
    char str1[] = "Hello";
    char str2[] = "World";
    strcat(str1, str2);
    printf("%s", str1);
    return 0;
}

What will be the output of the following C code?


void func() {
    static int x = 0;
    x++;
    printf("%d\n", x);
}
int main() {
    func();
    func();
    return 0;
}

What will be the output of the following C code?


int *getPointer() {
    int x = 10;
    return &x;
}
int main() {
    int *p = getPointer();
    printf("%d\n", *p);
    return 0;
}

What will be the output of the following C code?



int main() {
    int a = 5;
    printf("%d %d %d\n", a++, ++a, a);
    return 0;
}

Given the union definition:


union Data {
    int i;
    float f;
    char str[20];
};


What is the size of the union on a typical 32-bit system?

    printf("%s\n", arr[1]);

}

What will be the output of the following C++ code?


using namespace std;

class Base {
public:
    virtual void display() = 0;
};

class Derived : public Base {
public:
    void display() {
        cout << "Derived Class" << endl;
    }
};

int main() {
    Base *ptr;
    Derived obj;
    ptr = &obj;
    ptr->display();
    return 0;
}

What will be the output of the following C++ code?


using namespace std;

class Base {
public:
    virtual void show() = 0;
};

class Derived : public Base {
public:
    void show() {
        cout << "Derived Class" << endl;
    }
};

int main() {
    Derived obj;
    obj.show();
    return 0;
}

What is the output of the following code?


using namespace std;

class A {
public:
    void display() {
        cout << "A";
    }
};

class B : public A {
public:
    void display() {
        cout << "B";
    }
};

int main() {
    A obj;
    B* bptr = dynamic_cast<B*>(&obj);
    if (bptr) {
        bptr->display();
    } else {
        cout << "C";
    }
    return 0;
}

What will be the output of the following C++ code?


using namespace std;

class Base {
public:
    virtual void display() {
        cout << "Base Class" << endl;
    }
};

class Derived : public Base {
public:
    void display() override {
        cout << "Derived Class" << endl;
    }
};

int main() {
    Base *ptr;
    Derived obj;
    ptr = &obj;
    ptr->display();
    return 0;
}

What will be the output of the following C++ code?


using namespace std;

class Base {
public:
    void display() {
        cout << "Base Class" << endl;
    }
};

class Derived : public Base {
public:
    void display() {
        cout << "Derived Class" << endl;
    }
};

int main() {
    Derived obj;
    obj.display();
    return 0;
}

What will be the output of the following C++ code?


using namespace std;

class B;

class A {
    int x;
public:
    A(int i) : x(i) {}
    friend class B;
};

class B {
public:
    void display(A obj) {
        cout << obj.x << endl;
    }
};

int main() {
    A obj(10);
    B b;
    b.display(obj);
    return 0;
}

What will be the output of the following C++ code?


using namespace std;

class Test {
    int x;
public:
    Test(int i) : x(i) {}
    friend void display(Test obj);
};

void display(Test obj) {
    cout << obj.x << endl;
}

int main() {
    Test obj(10);
    display(obj);
    return 0;
}

What will be the output of the following C++ code?


namespace MyNamespace {
    void display() {
        std::cout << "MyNamespace" << std::endl;
    }
}

int main() {
    MyNamespace::display();
    return 0;
}

What will be the output of the following C++ code?


using namespace std;

template<class T>
class Test {
public:
    void display() {
        cout << "Generic Template" << endl;
    }
};

template <>
class Test<int> {
public:
    void display() {
        cout << "Specialized Template for int" << endl;
    }
};

int main() {
    Test<int> obj;
    obj.display();
    return 0;
}

questions.question: In the context of normalization, what is a partial dependency?

options.b: A dependency in which a non-key attribute determines the entire key.

options.d: A dependency in which one key attribute determines another key attribute.
